newsitem.title: UK: NatWest sees pronounced post-election UK rate rise.
newsitem.headline: NatWest sees pronounced post-election UK rate rise.

text.p: NatWest Group chief economist David Kern said pronounced increases in official interest rates would be necessary after Britain's general election, due by May.

"As output continues to expand at a rate above its long-term trend, there is increased likelihood that underlying RPI inflation will remain above 2.5 percent," he said, referring to the government's medium-term inflation target.
"Pronounced base rate rises will be required after the general election to dampen accelerating demand and stronger inflation."
He sees official rates rising fairly sharply from the present 6.0 percent from May onwards, peaking at 7.25 percent by the end of 1997.
Base rates should fall back again to 6.75 percent by the end of 1998 as the economy slows, Kern said.
The strong pound would probably enable Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke to keep rates unchanged until the election.

"But strong unemployment falls and higher earnings growth point to a tightening labour market and these pressures will increase later in the year," Kern wrote in NatWest's latest Economic and Financial Outlook.
